recs.title: Hummingbird feeders
recs.content: One of the most satisfying things I've gotten into during the pandemic is feeding hummingbirds. Early last year I set up a bunch of hummingbird feeders on my deck and I cannot recommend it enough. One, it helps the birds, many of whom are migrating over large urban landscapes, have enough food to make it through their journey. Two, it's extremely peaceful and meditative to watch birds. Hummingbirds are very territorial and you can watch them duck and war with each other for hours. If you're patient enough and develop enough of a relationship with them they'll even feed out of a feeder on your hand.¬†

feature.title: #115: Taylor Lorenz (NYT)
feature.intro: Taylor Lorenz is a Los Angeles based journalist covering memes, YouTubers, TikTokers, Twitch streamers, and more for the New York Times. Her deep curiosity of Internet culture has led to great pieces on everything from the text-heavy meme posts of pages like @on_a_downward_spiral and @lifes.a.bender, the word ‚ÄúCheugy‚Äù, and @glamdemon2004‚Äôs rise on TikTok. Right now she‚Äôs hard at work on her upcoming book, Extremely Online, which charts the rise of the so-called "creator economy" or influencer economy. You can expect to find Extremely Online from Simon & Schuster in late 2022. Taylor has great taste and lucky for us, she‚Äôs here to tell us what she‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: FlowState.fm
recs.content: FlowState is an awesome daily newsletter that sends two hours of music that's perfect for working to. There's no algorithmic discovery, it's all human recommendations and they write a little blurb about each artist they feature. It consistently introduces me to new artists I didn't know and has helped me appreciate lots of new genres, especially in the ambient music realm. The newsletter also puts out custom mixes and private Spotify playlists for paid subscribers.¬†

recs.title: Channel 5 News
recs.content: Channel 5 News is one of the only media startups I'm excited about. People might remember Andrew Callaghan, Nic Mosher, and Evan Gilbert-Katz from their YouTube and Instagram show All Gas No Brakes. They parted ways with their management company last year and ever since they left they've really hit their stride. The group roves around America in a vintage news van reporting from the ground on events like a Pick Up Artist Bootcamp, L.A. punk shows, a Qanon conference, a white lives matter rally, and more. Andrew and his team produced some of the best on the ground coverage of big breaking news events last year and I can't wait to see what Channel 5 puts out next.¬†

recs.title: "The Fool‚Äù
recs.content: the fool, also known as the clown, is a touchstone of memes concerning the self-reflexivity of one‚Äôs own silliness, or more likely her foolishness. no more: silliness is the highest form of morality. i was watching an episode of rupaul‚Äôs drag race: untucked recently‚Äîseason 2, which corresponds to rupaul‚Äôs drag race season 3, because the first season had no untucked‚Äîand there was shangela: leering, musing whether or not she‚Äôd been set up to be ‚Äúthe fool‚Äù in the wake of some foul play involving the construction of a gown made out of hair. there is valor in being deceived, shangela! there is even glamour in looking dumb. if you‚Äôre reading this you‚Äôre uncool: so why fake it?

feature.title: #111: Hari Nef
feature.intro: Hari Nef is an actress, model, and writer based in New York City. You may know Hari from the Emmy-winning television series Transparent or Sam Levinson's Assassination Nation, but she also tells me that she‚Äôll be on the next season of ‚Äúyour favorite show‚Äù, but that it‚Äôs still a secret üòâ. In the last year she‚Äôs penned pieces such as The Agony and the Ecstasy of Getting Mistaken for Cis for GQ, multiple essays for Art Forum, and a fantastic John Waters profile for L'Officiel US. And the next time you‚Äôre trying to find something to watch I highly recommend checking out her letterboxd account, it‚Äôs been a constant stream of movie recs over the last year. Hari has great taste and lucky for us, she‚Äôs here to tell us what she‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: Black Market Pesto
recs.content: I have to be fair and give Casey Neistat credit for this one because he brought this pesto over to my house a few months ago and told me it would be the best pesto I've ever had. He was 10000% correct. Black Market Pesto is raw vegan pesto made with almonds rather than pine nuts. I cannot overstate how good this pesto is, I eat this stuff straight from the jar. It's made by this guy named Hunter Weiss in San Diego. For a while they were only delivering locally around the L.A. area, but I believe he's in the process of trying to organize a wider rollout according to his Twitter. For now, the pesto is sold out on their website and only comes in "drops" but you can leave your email to find out when they make more.¬†

recs.title: Yaki Ramen from Ramen Adente
recs.content: So I work in Williamsburg and as of lately I have been obsessed with this place called ramen adante. I used be a big pho person, still love pho but it‚Äôs hard to find good Vietnamese in New York. Anyways I have been ordering this dish called yaki ramen, it‚Äôs a broth less ramen with chicken meat and chicken broth, hands down amazing.¬†

feature.title: #113: Aaron Wiggs
feature.intro: Last summer, at the height of Black Lives Matter protests, Aaron Wiggs and his friends Sachiko Clyde & Perry Goodman decided to raise some money with ‚ÄúSidewalk Sales‚Äù. At first it was just them selling clothes from their own closets, but between the community coming together and the incredible commercials from Wigg‚Äôs alter-ego ‚ÄúUncle Leroy‚Äù, the sale quickly expanded to include all sorts of vendors and even Chlo√´ Sevigny shared some garments of her own for the cause. The Sidewalk Sales ended up raising over $260K for charities and community causes such as Emergency Release Funds and Black Trans Femmes in Art, and Wiggs says that he couldn‚Äôt have done it without ‚ÄúMax,¬†Price, Lylynn, Angel, Drew, Andrew B. Ian, Michael Fox, Stephen, Tyler, Dylan, Brandon, Perry, Sachiko, Mike, Tom, Brianna, Cam, and Lynette‚Äù. Aaron has great taste and lucky for us, he‚Äôs here to tell us what he‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: VAMPIRE WEEKEND
recs.content: Vampire Weekend is the best band of all time. I exclusively listen to Edith Piaf, the Newsies Soundtrack, and Vampire Weekend. But mostly Vampire Weekend. I play that shit on repeat all day long. I wake up and listen to ‚ÄúHorchata‚Äù for about an hour, then I move on to the song ‚ÄúStep‚Äù and then for the rest of the day, walking around New York, I listen to their album ‚ÄúFather of the Bride.‚Äù I fell in love for the first time to the sounds of Vampire Weekend, and so I just don‚Äôt see the point in listening to anything else. I‚Äôve never had sex to Vampire Weekend but my next boyfriend will love doing that, I just know it. VW‚Äôs music lifts me up and shoves me down and makes me nostalgic for things I have and haven‚Äôt had. Their music works well in every country. I feel like life is big and beautiful and that I‚Äôm absolutely unstoppable when ‚ÄúI Stand Corrected‚Äù is blasting. People like to say I have terrible taste in music but I disagree. Also, there is nothing ironic about my praise here. I love Vampire Weekend. I hope one day I become semi-famous so that they will have no choice but to play at my wedding.¬†

feature.title: #112: Annie Hamilton
feature.intro: Annie Hamilton is a NYC-based actress that you may know from films such as Jim Cummings‚Äô ‚ÄúThe Wolf of Snow¬†Hollow‚Äù or Kristoffer Borgli‚Äôs ‚ÄúDrib‚Äù, and soon you‚Äôll see her in the new season of Dickinson on Apple & alongside Diane Keaton in the upcoming comedy ‚ÄúMack and Rita‚Äù. In addition to her acting she‚Äôs had some great podcast appearances on The Ion Pack and Throwing Fits, and is even coming out with her very own podcast that‚Äôs sort of a mockumentary of her own life. Occasionally she pens very funny yet thoughtful journal entries for her Substack ‚ÄúAnnie Hamilton‚Äôs Words‚Äù and applies that same wit and humor to her prolific Twitter and Instagram posting. Annie has great taste and lucky for us, she‚Äôs here to tell us what she‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: LIPLINER
recs.content: I am a thin waisted and thin lipped woman. I like being thin waisted but it makes me queasy and sad that I have tiny little lips. My mom thinks my lips are elegant because Marlene Dietrich also had no upper lip but when you google ‚Äúthin lipped actress‚Äù Marlene‚Äôs just about the only respectable example who pops up. I don‚Äôt want plastic surgery because I am an ACTOR and I don‚Äôt believe the point of acting is to look beautiful all the time. ¬†Actors need to convey all sorts of feelings - of joy and desperation and mania - on their faces! Actors are not models! ¬†I could go on about this but I‚Äôll sound stupid, ¬†especially when I turn 50 and wind up with a face lift. Anyway, since in my day-to-day life I really do like looking ‚Äúbeautiful‚Äù I use lipliner to give myself an upper lip and change the shape of my mouth completely. Sometimes people don‚Äôt recognize me when I don‚Äôt have lipliner on, which makes me feel like a real chameleon. The only hard part about painting your face is that it means lots of trips to the bathroom when you first begin dating someone (reapplying between smooches). It is certainly a lot of upkeep. Right now I use Sephora brand lipliner as a base (it‚Äôs also only 6 dollars!) in ‚Äúlight brown.‚Äù Then I trace around the edges with a darker shade, Rimmel‚Äôs Lasting Finish in ‚Äúcappuccino.‚Äù They discontinued my favorite Kevyn Aucoin one so now when I‚Äôm feeling fancy I‚Äôll use Kjaer Weis‚Äôs lip pencil in ‚Äúrich.‚Äù I like nudes and browns. Never peach. Never. Peach.

recs.title: Ô∏è AN EXCERPT FROM CHERYL STRAYED‚ÄôS ‚ÄúDEAR SUGAR‚Äù COLUMN
recs.content:
People often ask me for relationship advice because I have an unhinged Twitter account that documents my romantic pitfalls. I find it to be pretty disconcerting considering I am an emotional monster and a loser in the sack, but for some reason, cute college girls still come knocking.¬†

I have a compulsive need to share everything I‚Äôm thinking to anyone who will listen, but I‚Äôve never gone into explicit detail about my last relationship partly because I really respect my ex, ¬†and partly because I still don‚Äôt know what to make of it. I cheated on him. It was awful. I promised myself I‚Äôd never be unfaithful again because I know no greater pain than hurting the person you love. My last ex is the only person I‚Äôve ever broken up with, and it took me forever to do it. First, we went on a break. Then, we got back together. Then he proposed. I didn‚Äôt say no but I didn‚Äôt say yes either. It took three months to fully break up, and it was only until I read this article that I was able to muster the courage to do the damn thing. I loved my ex with all my heart - in ways I still love him - and it was so hard to part ways because ¬†he hadn‚Äôt done anything ‚Äúwrong.‚Äù He was impossibly dedicated to me. Impossibly kind, impossibly smart, impossibly loving. But I knew things weren‚Äôt working. I knew I wanted more. Anyway, this article says it better than I can. Bottom line: If there is a ‚Äútiny clear voice‚Äù inside you that is saying ‚ÄúGO‚Äù, you must listen to it.¬†

My last ex is the only person I‚Äôve ever broken up with, and it took me forever to do it. First, we went on a break. Then, we got back together. Then he proposed. recs.title: Fire Island Pines
recs.content: the pines have a dubious reputation: a strip-of-a-strip of hamptons-adjacent driftwood crawling with rich white gay weekend warriors desperate to party and play among the island‚Äôs native pines and its unethically-imported bamboos. this is not untrue! but i spent a month there this summer, and i found myself amused and even inspired by the pines‚Äô inherent theatricality. every single house‚Äîfor better or for worse‚Äîis a stage set for someone‚Äôs idea of gay heaven. the itinerary of every chosen fam on their weekend or week-long excursion comprises a script for a queer friend group at its absolute best: ‚Äúwe cook! we swim in the ocean at night! we take ghb and 2cb! we smoke cigarettes and discuss auto-fiction! we fight about auto-fiction!‚Äù the pines are possibilities

recs.title: Pig
recs.content: A film that someone called a ‚Äútone poem‚Äù??? about the few things in life we get to really care about. It‚Äôs a sullen, deeply hurt performance from Nic, fighting for the principle of the things he loves. It felt a bit like Roadrunner, the Bourdain flick, in its celebration of the hard work us food and bevvies do- an insight into how we think and feel about our jobs. It resonated with me, it felt like relief.¬†

recs.content: Nothing like the great outdoors. recs.title: Jimmy Eat World‚Äôs 1999-2004 album run
recs.content: If you follow me on any social media platform, you‚Äôre likely aware of my emo tendencies, which I assure you are not just an elaborate bit. The albums that have remained in the heaviest rotation thus far in my life come from Jimmy Eat World ‚Äî specifically the three that dropped in succession during my middle and high school years: Clarity (1999), Bleed American (2001), and Futures (2004). Whether you want pop-punk bangers (‚ÄúSweetness‚Äù), tearjerkers that could soundtrack a pivotal scene in a teen drama (‚Äú23,‚Äù ‚ÄúHear You Me‚Äù), or the perfect song to put on a playlist for your crush (‚ÄúFor Me This Is Heaven‚Äù), there‚Äôs something here for everyone! For an optimal listening experience, queue these up during a windows-down night drive.

recs.title: üèª ‚ÄúMeet the Barkers‚Äù on YouTube
recs.content: I watched an obscene amount of early-to-mid 2000s reality TV during quarantine, including this delightful MTV series starring Travis Barker and his then-wife, model/actress Shanna Moakler. Viewers can tell the couple is keeping it totally real in front of the cameras: Travis was at the height of his Blink-182 fame while becoming a father for the first time, and watching the Barkers balance their hard-partying rock star lives with starting a family is endearing.

recs.title: A Course in Miracles
recs.content: I discovered this book over 30 years ago when I was having trouble forgiving a friend for something which, in hindsight, wasn‚Äôt that big a deal. But my unforgiveness was killing me and making me into an unbearable person. It‚Äôs a channeled book, and claims to be channeled by the historical Jesus. I know that sounds kooky, but it is the single most life-changing book that I have ever read. It completely changed my way of thinking not only about forgiveness but also about reality and the meaning of life. I have never read a book with a voice this absolutely authoritative and egoless at the same time. It‚Äôs not for everyone, but I can‚Äôt recommend this book highly enough.

feature.intro: As some of you may recall, I noted in our 100th post that Betsey Brown‚Äôs Caveh Zahedi recommendation (which is a great introduction btw) was my favorite rec of the newsletter thus far, so we‚Äôre very pleased that the man himself was down to come on Perfectly Imperfect and share some of his favorite things with us. Caveh is a filmmaker best known for his experimental & personal films ‚ÄúI Am a Sex Addict‚Äù and ‚ÄúI Don't Hate Las Vegas Anymore‚Äù, and cult classic TV show ‚ÄúThe Show About the Show‚Äù. However, Caveh needs our help, the future of ‚ÄúThe Show About the Show‚Äù is hanging by the thread of a Kickstarter campaign that ends on September 12th. I promise that if you watch one episode of the hyper-meta & almost too real show you‚Äôll be sold on Zahedi‚Äôs genius, so please check it out right away. Caveh has great taste and lucky for us, he‚Äôs here to tell us what he‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: Harlequin clown lamp
recs.content: I recently (finally!) after months of searching and not wanting to spend too much money, found the Pierrot clown lamp of my dreams on Willhaben (Austrian equivalent of Craigslist). He‚Äôs the perfect shade of a robin‚Äôs egg turquoise-y blue, I cleaned him with a toothbrush and some soap after having picked him up collecting dust in Vienna‚Äôs 22nd district, took him back home on the U-Bahn with me and we‚Äôve been having a whale of a time ever since. I feel happy every time I switch him on.

feature.title: #84: Sofie Fatouretchi Royer
feature.intro: Vienna‚Äôs Sofie Fatouretchi Royer is an artist of many disciplines‚Äî not only does she study painting at the University of Applied Arts in Austria but she‚Äôs the former Creative Director of the Boiler Room, been a Resident DJ at NTS since 2013, and in the midst of the pandemic she dropped her self-produced debut album, Cult Survivor, on Stones Throw Records. Her debut combines the baroque vocal style of 70s songwriters with lo-fi hypnagogic pop to create a lush, melancholy, beautiful, and melodic sound that I really love. If you like what you hear, be sure to check out the music video for ‚ÄúHollywood Walk of Fame‚Äú (made with Eugene Kotlyarenko) and know that she‚Äôs working on her second studio album! Sofie has great taste and lucky for us, she‚Äôs here to talk about what she‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: Thomas the Obscure by Maurice Blanchot
recs.content: This is the book I have read more times than any other. I don‚Äôt think any other (human) writer has ever reached the spiritual heights that Blanchot achieved in this book. His work has been a beacon to me ever since I discovered it in college. Most of the people I‚Äôve recommended this book to did NOT love it, but those that did became lifelong fanatics. It‚Äôs abstruse and almost every sentence is a mind-fuck, but I would argue that Blanchot is the greatest writer ever.

recs.title: Ô∏è Andrei Roublev by Andrei Tarkovsky
recs.content: Tarkovsky is arguably the greatest filmmaker of all time and, for me, Andrei Roublev is his greatest film. Every single shot in this film is a masterpiece - every frame, every camera move, every chiaroscuro effect. It tells the story of one of Russia‚Äôs greatest religious icon painters, but in such a ramshackle way that it becomes an allegory of the creative process and what it means to be an artist. The film surprises at every turn ‚Äì not a single moment is predictable. The final scene is one of the greatest endings in all of cinema, right up there with the end of Lars Von Trier‚Äôs¬†Melancholia¬†and the end of Robert Bresson‚Äôs¬†The Devil Probably.

recs.title: The Collected Poems of Wallace Stevens
recs.content: The poetry of Wallace Stevens has been the single greatest help to me in living my life. He taught me to see the world ‚Äúcleansed of its stiff and stubborn man-locked set.‚Äù He taught me to apprehend the deeper mystery that is Reality, and to quote Stevens, to see ‚Äúhow much of what he saw he never saw at all.‚Äù He taught me to understand that Reality is not a solid but, perhaps, ‚Äúa shade that traverses a dust/a force that traverses a shade.‚Äù He taught me to be at peace in the world and I will forever be in his debt.¬†

recs.title: The Reeder App
recs.content: I was a rather die-hard anti RSS internet guy for quite some time. I wanted to soak in the design of the site - likely a left-over behavior from the magazine culture days. Reality is, once you properly load whatever¬†RSS reader you prefer, it's kinda hard to even figure out how to go back. It helps me consume all the information of the day quickly and with effectively no advertising or unneeded visual distraction and it syncs across all my devices, etc. I find the Reeder app itself to be incredibly elegant in it's subtle attention to detail and one-handed use. Real nerd stuff. ¬†¬†

Benjamin has great taste and lucky for us, he‚Äôs here to talk about what he‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: International Design Yearbooks
recs.content:
I‚Äôve seen these annual digests of the best in product innovation around forever but only started buying them recently. I grabbed one at a place in LA that had loads of dusty design books on the cheap. Not long after that, I went to a Housing Works on the UES because someone on TikTok said it had the best clothing selection. It didn‚Äôt, but they did have 2 of these for $10 each.

They‚Äôre pure cheat code. Every good idea that‚Äôs being ripped off by contemporary artisans is in one of these - lamps bent into unnatural shapes, shelves that don‚Äôt look like they hold very much, dinnerware that you‚Äôd never dare eat off of. The designs are Italian and Japanese, of course, but also Finnish, Canadian, Spanish, even American. Each edition has a different luminary as an editor: Arata Isozaki, Mario Bellini, Philippe Starck, freakin‚Äô Alessandro Mendini. They‚Äôre tidy, portable museums.

feature.title: #104: Jon Caramanica (NYT)
feature.intro: Brooklyn‚Äôs Jon Caramanica is a pop music critic at the New York Times and the writer of the men's Critical Shopper column. At the Times he‚Äôs penned great pieces such as Into the Wild With Kanye West (keep an eye out for Jon‚Äôs upcoming book on Kanye West and American Culture) and New York, It‚Äôs Time to Shop!, a round-up of the exciting new stores such as Kathleen Sorbara‚Äôs Chickee‚Äôs Vintage, Bijan Shahvali‚Äôs Leisure Center, and Andrew Chen‚Äôs 3Sixteen. In addition to his pop music writing, he‚Äôs also the host of the NYT‚Äôs Popcast, a podcast where he covers the latest in music trends and news. Jon has great taste and lucky for us, he‚Äôs here to talk about what he‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: Begonia Maculata (aka the Polka Dot Begonia)
recs.content: I found out about this gem of a plant in January and immediately went out and brought one home from GRDN. I truly feel like I discovered both the easiest and happiest plant to grow inside of an NYC apartment. For reference - here is my begonia on my bedside table 7 months ago, and here it is today...WILD right?! Also it occasionally sprouts little white flowers which is insanely cute. Go get yourself one and put it in a spot with filtered light so it can sunbathe all year longggg.

feature.title: #103: Coolstuff.nyc
feature.intro: I, like many of us, subscribed to far too many newsletters in 2020‚Ä¶but Anna & Garrett‚Äôs coolstuff.nyc is on the shortlist of ones I actually open each week. They have a real knack for distilling the latest events, restaurants, art shows, and shops that I should care about, along with neighborhood guides and ‚ÄúCool Friend‚Äù Interviews (pshhht, check out mine from last week), into a digestible and well-designed no bullshit newsletter. When they‚Äôre not working on their ‚Äòsletter Anna is a Textile & Rug designer who freelances as an Interior Stylist & Content Creator, and Garrett is a Product Designer and a co-founder of Where are the Black Designers, a volunteer-run, nonprofit design advocacy organization aiming to heal, support, amplify, and make space for the entire spectrum of Black creativity. Garrett and Anna have great taste and lucky for us, they‚Äôre here to tell us what they‚Äôve been into.

recs.title: Frank Heath
recs.content:
Part How To with John Wilson, Part Channel 5, part Longmont Potion Castle‚Ä¶I got introduced to the work of Frank Heath last year by my much smarter friend Noa Ryan so I‚Äôll just let her speak on it:

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a sad, funny comfort in Frank Heath‚Äôs multimedia work, which is generally about humanity, bureaucracy, and the end of the world (and the ‚Äúend of the world‚Äù). It‚Äôs equal parts playful and careful, joining research, make-believe and aesthetic acuity in what end up feeling like gestures of tenderness towards the tragicomedy of human affairs and longings. If you are looking for cynicism you won‚Äôt find it here, but you might end up liking the alternative :)‚Äù

PS: If you have a link for Crypts of Civilization or Last Will and Testament hit my line.

feature.title: #102: Shy's Burgers and Frys
feature.intro: Shyan and¬†Alex are the dudes behind Shy‚Äôs Burgers and Frys, a burger operation run from a flat top grill on their balcony that‚Äôs focused around an unpretentious four(ish) item menu and high-quality ingredients. Stop by their Williamsburg apartment, yell your order up to the balcony, and a few minutes later NYC‚Äôs coolest burger will be lowered down in a little red bucket along with a Miracle Seltzer or Pony-sized beer‚Äî what more could you need? They‚Äôve since expanded from their friends & family events to bigger pop-ups at art shows, Cactus Store NYC, Grimm Brewery, and events such as the Throwing Fits BBQ, and coming up on August 22nd they‚Äôll be at Flynn McGarry‚Äôs Gem. Shyan and Alex have great taste and lucky for us, they‚Äôre here to talk about what they‚Äôve been into.

recs.title: Living & Eating - John Pawson, and Annie Bell
recs.content:
It‚Äôs hard for me to earnestly recommend a cookbook this expensive (It‚Äôs out of print!), but Pawson‚Äôs first book, a rec of a rec via the New Yorker‚Äôs Helen Rosner, is singularly outstanding. Yes, yes...A cookbook from an Englishman? The thing is, it‚Äôs decidedly un-British, continental in all the best ways, modern in its disposition, and prescient in it‚Äôs cookbook design. As a very goofy dude, operating a very unsexy business, Pawson‚Äôs work is a godsend. He approaches food in a holistic way - less so a manifesto, more so a journey through his mind. First, the kitchen from its bones - counterspace, appliances, hobs, things of that nature. He is an architect after all. The ideal oven size? At least 900mm by the way. Alongside the 200+ recipes in the book you‚Äôll find some real elite food writing provided by Annie Bell. Brilliant and beautiful prose that you shouldn‚Äôt gloss over.¬†

Pawson recently released his second cookbook earlier this year titled Home Farm Cooking. I haven‚Äôt read it, but I reckon you should buy that instead. Don‚Äôt shell out hundreds of dollars on a cookbook unless you‚Äôre a collector or got money to burn. Live well.¬†

recs.title: The Ready State
recs.content:
Okay... I think honestly people are surprised to learn that I am deeply obsessed with like, ‚Äúhealth and fitness‚Äù culture. I think it is SO FUN and riveting and it occupies sooo much of my thoughts and my time. I have been told that this does not suit my personality. It‚Äôs like God flipped a wrong switch and gave ‚Äúloves to work out‚Äù to me instead of the right person. But if I was REALLY being honest in this list and not trying to impress anyone, all my recommendations would be about that. But I‚Äôm trying for some variety, so I will just say that the government does not want you to know about The Ready State.

Dr. Kelly Starrett is an amazing man. If you have a foam roller, lacrosse balls, tennis balls, a towel, NOTHING, there‚Äôs a 5/10/20/30 minute video you can do where you follow along with him as he talks you through mobilizing and restoring¬† function to your own tissues and muscular systems and teaches you how one affects the other etc. If that sounds really boring,¬† you don‚Äôt have to retain any of the information, you can just give yourself a better massage than anyone you would pay could. It hurts really bad fyi

I think everyone in the world should be devoting at least like 5 min a day to this. It will literally keep you from needing surgery later. ‚ÄúDoctors HATE him!‚Äù etc

(Equally great alternative, higher production value- Jill Miller‚Äôs YogaTuneUp balls --

--¬† and corresponding videos. I think she has a lot of free Youtube stuff too that might not even require lacrosse balls)

feature.title: #101: Dylan Gelula
feature.intro: Dylan Gelula is an actor that you may be familiar with from her roles in TV shows such as Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt (2015-2019) and movies like Ales Ross Perry‚Äôs Her Smell (2018), First Girl I Loved (2016), and Shithouse (2020)‚Äî early subscribers may even remember when I recommended Shithouse on Perfectly Imperfect waaaaay back in November 2020. Gelula is also one of the funniest people I follow on Twitter and the co-host of Lecture Hall, a podcast she runs with writer and actor Broti Gupta. Dylan has great taste and lucky for us, she‚Äôs here to tell us what she‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: ‚ÄçÔ∏è Nicole Wild Yoga
recs.content:
I love taking fitness classes IRL and I think boutique fitness is so interesting and literally, like I said, could just make this whole thing about that. So if you ARE interested in recommendations of studios and teachers and stuff reach out to me bc I am going to STOP but I did wanna say-- if you‚Äôre someone who‚Äôs been practicing yoga for a long time, especially at home, it can get kind of monotonous- you start to be able to predict where you‚Äôre going next, like, Warrior 2, then Reverse Warrior, then Triangle. Etc.¬†

So I recently found this girl I am in love with and her name is Nicole and she doesn‚Äôt upload videos very often but they‚Äôre like the closest to an in-studio experience I‚Äôve ever had at home. Her sequencing is so creative!!¬† She‚Äôs an artist. It‚Äôs definitely for more experienced people, but if that is you, I think you will love her. She is amazing at coming up with crazy flows that are so fun and challenging. And a lot of them are a nice hour long!!

If you are newer to yoga and are maybe burnt out on Adrienne, I think you would love Yoga With Kassandra...¬† she‚Äôs really accessible.. this is all free on YouTube I should have specified

recs.title: Trader Joe‚Äôs French Vanilla Coffee
recs.content: I tend to quickly (often negatively and almost always incorrectly) judge everyone and everything, and this blindingly shiny, incredibly difficult-to-open package of ground coffee was not spared from this ugly quality of mine. I was shocked to discover these grounds actually brew piping hot pots of coffee that make my apartment smell like a Dunkin‚Äô Donuts but taste as if Dunkin‚Äô Donuts‚Äô coffee didn‚Äôt taste like water. I start every morning with a cup of this, frothed with pistachio milk and a little maple syrup (bonus recs!!!), fueled up and searching for something new to (mis)judge.

feature.intro: Gaby and Courtney are the brains behind one of our favorite newsletters, Sifted, where a few times a week they filter through the endless ocean of recipes on the internet and recommend their favorites to cook (and sometimes tweak). You can think of them as restaurant critics, but for recipes. Perfectly Imperfect and Sifted have even had a handful of overlapping guests, Alex Delaney and Catherine Cohen to name a few, and we even dropped some Perfectly Imperfect recipe recs ourselves, so if you‚Äôre a fan of cool guests, recipes, and recommendations, you‚Äôre bound to love their ‚Äòsletter. recs.title: Nuts.com
recs.content: The selection of nuts on nuts.com is nuts, but so is the abundance of items that are not nuts. My orders always include a jar of their creamy-but-still-a-little-crunchy almond butter, but I also like to stock up on baking supplies like flaky sea salt, dark chocolate disks and 5-pound bags of sugar. As an apostle of nuts.com, I‚Äôve also helped numerous friends and strangers see the light. My boyfriend‚Äôs pantry is perpetually packed with their roasted edamame, dried mango and cheddar popcorn, and I always spot colorful bags of malted milk balls and chocolate covered espresso beans when I visit my parents‚Äô apartment. And while Courtney might be the only person who orders their crunchy marshmallow bits regularly, you‚Äôve gotta respect nuts.com for even having them in stock.¬†

recs.title: Perfect Popcorn
recs.content: If you, like me, take popcorn very seriously, you simply must try Anson Mills‚Äô popcorn. It is the first popcorn I‚Äôve tasted that truly tastes like-- get this-- corn! It‚Äôs subtly sweet and toasty and nuanced in ways that I‚Äôve never tasted from the popped stuff. Rancho Gordo popcorn is also tasty and a very dramatic color, but Anson Mills is on another level. As for popping, you can‚Äôt go wrong with the absolute game changer that is a Whirley Pop. Despite its goofy name and the annoying amount of cupboard space it occupies, it makes perfect popcorn. Every. Single. Time. No burnt pieces, no kernel left unpopped. And when they‚Äôre the best kernels you won‚Äôt want to waste any. From there, I adorn mine with a copious amount of salt, olive oil, and nutritional yeast or fresh parm. If it‚Äôs the fake butter you‚Äôre craving, may I suggest Butter Buds‚Ñ¢? They‚Äôre little butter-flavored granules I first had in grade school popcorn parties, and have loved for their unabashed artificiality ever since.

recs.title: Ô∏è John Derian Candles
recs.content: I aspire to fill my home with food, and also with things that look like food but are decidedly not food. From corn cob stools to garlic pillows to bread lamps, I want it all. Until I have a home, or museum to house all these objects, I‚Äôll continue on a small scale, building my collection of John Derian‚Äôs uncanny trompe l‚Äôoeil candles. Next up on my wish list are the Fruit Crostata and the Capocollo, naturally.¬†

recs.title: Black Sesame Paste
recs.content: Calling it now-- black sesame paste a.k.a. black tahini is about to have a moment. I love the Japanese and Taiwanese versions, which tend to be lightly sweetened with honey or sugar and the seeds toasted before being ground, adding even more depth of flavor. Black sesame paste tastes like peanut butter but way more intense and will make all your food look goth in the best possible way. I‚Äôve found it at Sunrise Mart, H Mart or Mitsuwa but you can obviously find it online as well. How to use it? The sky‚Äôs the limit, but my formula has generally been: good dessert + black sesame paste = even better dessert. Swirled into homemade ice cream, added to the filling of plush cinnamon buns, but best of all, mixed into nostalgic, chewy, perfect brown butter Rice Krispie treats.¬†

recs.title: Bright Lights. Big City
recs.content: This was the second book I‚Äôve ever read that‚Äôs written in the 2nd person. Previously, I found it hard to get used to, and honestly a little clunky. Somehow McInerney achieves to make this flow as easily as anything. It truly feels like you are the subject of the story. BL.BC follows you, a fact checker wanna-be-fiction-author at a big publication in Manhattan, as you waste away to late nights of coke binges and crowded parties. Praised often as one of the first great anti-quests, BL.BC achieves the great feat of making you care about, and enjoy, the miserable journey of such a win-less character. This is one of those reads that just feels iconic.

recs.title: A Guide to Pseudo-Events in America - Daniel J. Boorstin
recs.content: You know how there are some people you meet, and after meeting them, you begin to see them everywhere? They were always there, but once you know their name or their face, you realize just how present they already were in your life? This book is a bit like that for me. It‚Äôs not super niche, but for a book published in ‚Äò62, its predictions couldn‚Äôt have been more spot-on. Once you read it, everything it outlines and describes just emerges in your everyday life.¬† Boorstin coined the term ‚ÄúPseudo-Events‚Äù ‚Äî [ an event arranged or brought about merely for the sake of the publicity it generates] and it‚Äôs endlessly relevant in an era of constant openings, launch parties, etc.¬† Maybe you‚Äôre reading this on your way to a Pseudo-Event, maybe you are a human pseudo-event.

feature.title: #98: Dylan Chenfeld (Rebounder)
feature.intro: Dylan Chenfeld is the singer & frontman of the exciting NYC-based band, Rebounder, whose infectious blend of indie rock and pop has been creating a lot of buzz. At the end of June, they put out a brand new single featuring Jesse Rutherford of The Neighbourhood called ‚ÄúChange Shapes‚Äù, which is about ‚Äúthe idea that you are allowed to change how you feel, look, express yourself, and that it‚Äôs not all so rigid‚Äù. Rebounder is headlining their first show ever (with Toledo and Sedona opening) on August 9th at Elsewhere, you can buy tickets here (I‚Äôll be there!). Dylan has great taste and lucky for us, he‚Äôs here to talk about what he‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: Skateboard with longboard wheels
recs.content: I‚Äôve been skating forever, but about two years ago I got a new studio space that is pretty far from the nearest..anything. Around that time, a guy got really drunk at my local bodega and left his skateboard there. They held it for me the next day and gave it to me as a gift for not being a rude customer, and I began living life as a boy with two boards. Since I was moving into a new studio, I thought I‚Äôd leave the board @ the studio for any coffee runs. It‚Äôs a lifesaver. I threw risers underneath the trucks and big longboard wheels on it, and now I can cruise to the coffee shop really fast. I can‚Äôt go back and ride those loud little wheels anymore. Once you try this, that shit just isn‚Äôt fun.¬†

recs.title: "The Causeway Glasses" from The Quality Mending Co.
recs.content: I was on the hunt for a good pair of yellow-lensed sunglasses and luckily Cobey Arner of the band Rebounder (check your inbox this Thursday üòâ) was nice enough to supply me with the lens deets. Turns out the vintage shop The Quality Mending Co. makes some very sick handmade and polarized sunglasses at a pretty solid price point of $158 so I took the plunge. I really like the mellow tint of these lenses, they help shield my sensitive lil eyes from the late afternoon sun, a time of day that my other shades are overkill for.

recs.title: The Breeders
recs.content: I've been revisiting a bunch of 90s alt-rock as of late, but nothing has been as sticky to me as Last Splash and Pod, two great albums from seminal Ohio-based indie rock band, The Breeders. Chances are you've probably heard their hit song Cannonball, but be sure to check out Drivin' on 9, No Aloha, Doe, Saints, and their cover of Happiness is a Warm Gun, which all rule. Hell, just listen to both albums front to back.

recs.title: Les Rallizes D√©nud√©s
recs.content: I recently stumbled upon this legendary Japanese psychedelic rock band and was immediately sucked in. After diving a bit deeper I noticed them being repeatedly referred to as "the greatest band to never officially publish studio material". Take that with a grain of salt of course, but apparently this '77 Live album is their best collection of work (the song ,"Night of the assassins", rules), so check it out if you're interested.

recs.title: KAMAUU
recs.content: My friend put me on to KAMAUU recently with his single Mango and it gave me a Childish Gambino Redbone vibe and I was really into it. I figured I'd get some more low-pitched, groovy tracks with his other songs, but I was so wrong. His other single BOA was filled with straight bars with a powerful message. On the other hand, he's on Instagram (@kamauuworld) posting WEEKLY fire snippets of self-produced beats and verses. He's a really creative artists, even if you don't have the time to check out his full songs, just give this snippet a shot.

recs.title: lofi hip hop radio
recs.content: An ex-lover introduced me to this youtube channel that plays non-stop "beats to relax/study to" and honey it has become the soundtrack of my LIFE! I'm a library bitch (can't write if music has lyrics) so this ambient instrumental station is perfect to listen to while I'm trying to write the next great american instagram poem from the comforts of my own bed. and it goes without saying the girl in the video has become like family to me! she's sooo cozy & hygge & I really hope she gets everything she wants in this life. there is also some kind of community aspect to the station in the form of a constantly refreshing chat function that I don't understand and fear immensely, please don't explain it to me!

feature.title: #96: Catherine Cohen
feature.intro: Houston native Catherine Cohen is a comedian, actress, and writer living in Manhattan who hosts a weekly show at Club Cumming in NYC and co-hosts Seek Treatment, a popular podcast where she and Pat Regan talk about ‚Äúboys, sex, fucking, dating, and love‚Äù. You may recognize Cat from Michael Showalter‚Äôs The Lovebirds, Season 3 of High Maintenance on HBO, or from her prolific social media presence. Earlier this year Cat put out her debut poetry collection, God I Feel Modern¬†Tonight: Poems from a Gal About Town, that was published by Knopf. You can also subscribe to her newsletter, My Sexy Little Email, where 100% of all proceeds will go to The Loveland Foundation, an organization that funds therapy for Black women and girls. Catherine has great taste and lucky for us, she‚Äôs here to tell us what she‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: Acts of Desperation by Megan Nolan
recs.content: I hadn't read a novel in about 45 years (I only care about stuff that is true) but I absolutely fell in love with this book and truly could not put it down. Nolan's novel is about obsession, sex, love and booze and boy addiction-- all the hits. I've never brought a book (or myself) onto the elliptical, but cut to me last month at Equinox absolutely devouring this book while taking little slidey steps to and fro. By the way, last week I saw a girl on the treadmill with her hair down?????? Someone send an ambulance!

recs.title: Clarkson‚Äôs Farm
recs.content: I started watching¬†Clarkson‚Äôs Farm¬†the other night, the¬†Top Gear¬†of agriculture hosted by Jeremy Clarkson, who bought a 1000 acre estate in the Cotswolds in 2008 and then decided to farm it himself in 2019 when the local guy who managed it retired. In the first episode Jeremy buys a huge Lamborghini tractor, which is basically the only triumphant moment in the battle of man vs. nature that follows. You get the sense that Jeremy deeply regrets pitching the series in the first place. Meanwhile I'm hooked on browsing Lamborghini tractors online.

feature.title: #95: Samuel Hine (GQ)
feature.intro: Samuel Hine is the Senior Associate Editor of GQ and GQ Style, where he writes about fashion, beauty, celebrities, and influencers, among other things, and also co-hosts the GQ style podcast Corporate Lunch along with Rachel Seville Tashjian (check out her PI feature here) and Noah Johnson. A few months ago Sam dropped his first ever cover story, A$AP Rocky Is the Prettiest Man Alive, where they talk about Rocky‚Äôs time in a Swedish jail, his journey of self-discovery, musical experimentation, and love. Sam has great taste and lucky for us, he‚Äôs here to talk about what he‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: New York, New York by Marie Tomanova
recs.content: Czech photographer Marie Tomanova has dope style and takes beautiful flicks documenting NYC youth culture. She has a new monograph out at the end of September called New York, New York that I can‚Äôt wait to get. (Full disclosure: I‚Äôm in it lmao.) Marie has one of the most infectious senses of optimism that I‚Äôve ever encountered, and her first book, Young American, caught fire when it came out in 2019 because of how hopeful and empowered her subjects appear. Like Young American, NY, NY is probably going to sell out and become one of those rare coffee table books that occasionally comes up on Japanese eBay for $1,000, so shoutout to Antwaun Sargent who‚Äôs bringing me back a copy from the Rencontres d'Arles photo festival where it was announced.¬†

recs.title: Ô∏è CAVEH ZAHEDI
recs.content: The fact that Caveh Zahedi is not a household name is proof that sometimes the best art goes unnoticed.¬†His work consists of astoundingly intimate portraits of himself, his family, his process, and the difficulty of communication. He embodies radical honesty and faith.¬†I started my obsession with Caveh watching his film, ‚ÄúI Don‚Äôt Hate Las Vegas Anymore,‚Äù which you can find¬†on youtube. ‚ÄúI Don‚Äôt Hate Las Vegas Anymore‚Äù is an awe-inspiring 70 minute personal documentary in which Caveh invites a¬†minuscule¬†film crew to document his weekend in Las Vegas with his father and half brother, where he asks them to take ecstasy with him in order to deepen their relationship.¬†If 70 minutes feels like too much, his TV show, "The Show about the Show‚Äù are each a brilliant 17ish minutes¬†with each episode about the making of the previous¬†episode (check out his Kickstarter campaign for the show¬†here. He'll be making a mini-season about his crowdfunding experience as a part of said campaign...god damn I love him).¬† If THAT seems too long, his podcast ‚Äú365 stories I want to tell you before I die‚Äù are 1-5 minute¬†episodes about his life and he has been putting one out every day of 2021.¬†When I'm making my own work, I often ask myself, "What would Caveh do?" He's become the pinnacle.¬†There‚Äôs a lot to check out with Caveh and I¬†command that you check him out NOW!
recs.contentHTML: The fact that Caveh Zahedi is not a household name is proof that sometimes the best art goes unnoticed. His work consists of astoundingly intimate portraits of himself, his family, his process, and the difficulty of communication. He embodies radical honesty and faith. I started my obsession with Caveh watching his film, ‚ÄúI Don‚Äôt Hate Las Vegas Anymore,‚Äù which you can find on youtube. ‚ÄúI Don‚Äôt Hate Las Vegas Anymore‚Äù is an awe-inspiring 70 minute personal documentary in which Caveh invites a minuscule film crew to document his weekend in Las Vegas with his father and half brother, where he asks them to take ecstasy with him in order to deepen their relationship. If 70 minutes feels like too much, his TV show, "The Show about the Show‚Äù are each a brilliant 17ish minutes with each episode about the making of the previous episode (check out his Kickstarter campaign for the show here. He'll be making a mini-season about his crowdfunding experience as a part of said campaign...god damn I love him).  If THAT seems too long, his podcast ‚Äú365 stories I want to tell you before I die‚Äù are 1-5 minute episodes about his life and he has been putting one out every day of 2021. When I'm making my own work, I often ask myself, "What would Caveh do?" He's become the pinnacle. There‚Äôs a lot to check out with Caveh and I command that you check him out NOW!

feature.title: #94: Betsey Brown
feature.intro: Betsey Brown is a Manhattan-based actor and filmmaker who recently starred in Dasha Nekrasova‚Äôs 2021 debut feature film, ‚ÄúThe Scary of Sixty-First‚Äù, which won the GWFF Best First Feature Award at Berlin International Film Festival.¬†She‚Äôs also the star of the cult-hit ‚ÄúAssholes‚Äù (written and directed by her brother Peter Vack) which won the inaugural Adam Yauch Hornblower Award at SXSW. ¬†Brown‚Äôs short film ‚Äúshegetsey betsey‚Äù, which she wrote, directed, shot, edited,¬†and starred in won¬†the Audience Award for Best Experimental Short Film at the New Orleans Film Festival and her debut feature as a writer, director, and star is titled ‚ÄúActors‚Äù & will be released at the end of the year by Factory 25! Betsey has great taste and lucky for us, she‚Äôs here to talk about what she‚Äôs been into.
feature.introHTML: Betsey Brown is a Manhattan-based actor and filmmaker who recently starred in Dasha Nekrasova‚Äôs 2021 debut feature film, ‚ÄúThe Scary of Sixty-First‚Äù, which won the GWFF Best First Feature Award at Berlin International Film Festival. She‚Äôs also the star of the cult-hit ‚ÄúAssholes‚Äù (written and directed by her brother Peter Vack) which won the inaugural Adam Yauch Hornblower Award at SXSW.  Brown‚Äôs short film ‚Äúshegetsey betsey‚Äù, which she wrote, directed, shot, edited, and starred in won the Audience Award for Best Experimental Short Film at the New Orleans Film Festival and her debut feature as a writer, director, and star is titled ‚ÄúActors‚Äù & will be released at the end of the year by Factory 25! Betsey has great taste and lucky for us, she‚Äôs here to talk about what she‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: Noodles Stewed with Young Curry Chicken at HK WONTON GARDEN
recs.content: HK Wonton Garden on Mulberry Street is a Brown family staple.¬†I even feel a little conflicted telling you about it tbh. It is already too crowded sometimes.¬†My parents would take us to Chinatown almost every¬†Sunday¬†of my youth to get ‚Äúwonton and noodle soup‚Äù which for me was just ‚Äúnoodle soup‚Äù because I was a picky eater. The noodles are unbeatable, but I couldn‚Äôt go my whole life just ordering ‚Äúnoodle soup,‚Äù so when I was a teen my high school boyfriend (big shouts Chris) and I decided to broaden our horizons and take a chance on ‚ÄúNoodles Stewed with Young Curry Chicken,‚Äù (mostly because of it's funny borderline-unappetizing¬†name) and I‚Äôve never looked back.¬†It's my favorite dish in NYC and what I order every time.¬† And that's not changing anytime soon.
recs.contentHTML: HK Wonton Garden on Mulberry Street is a Brown family staple. I even feel a little conflicted telling you about it tbh. It is already too crowded sometimes. My parents would take us to Chinatown almost every Sunday of my youth to get ‚Äúwonton and noodle soup‚Äù which for me was just ‚Äúnoodle soup‚Äù because I was a picky eater. The noodles are unbeatable, but I couldn‚Äôt go my whole life just ordering ‚Äúnoodle soup,‚Äù so when I was a teen my high school boyfriend (big shouts Chris) and I decided to broaden our horizons and take a chance on ‚ÄúNoodles Stewed with Young Curry Chicken,‚Äù (mostly because of it's funny borderline-unappetizing name) and I‚Äôve never looked back. It's my favorite dish in NYC and what I order every time.  And that's not changing anytime soon.

recs.title: Grape Waterloo
recs.content: Thank GOD someone noticed there was a giant gaping purple hole in the seltzer water industrial complex! I'm not sure how Grape came to be the overlooked flavor during the seltzer water boom, but I'm glad Waterloo stepped in to fix it with their Grape sparkling water flavor. They describe it as a "nostalgic" taste and I would agree - it's got the whole grape soda vibe going without all the sugar. It's about time we started to re-normalize grape¬†flavors.¬†It's also low-key rare, which makes finding it and enjoying it all the more fun. With a squeeze of lemon? Bliss. If you enjoyed grape lollipops as a kid (or adult, fuck it), you'll love. Now we just need some grape vodka to mix it with....

recs.title: üèº SolaWave
recs.content: I got a SolaWave last month and I pick it up almost nightly. It's this futuristic wand thing that combines microcurrents (tea) with red light therapy (wig) to make your skin....better? It gets warm and vibrates while you lightly wave it over your skin. I kept seeing it in Instagram ads so to try the real thing is very satisfying. You know, after watching complete strangers get paid to talk about how they don't have wrinkles anymore because of it. Wonderful! I'm luckily not old enough to have¬†that¬†many wrinkles, but I think it does even out tone and make my skin tighter? All I know is that I've tried Gua Sha and it was very hard to stick to. I think this has a similar vibe of being something-you-Do-for-your-Skin, but it's more futuristic and does the work for you. For my aesthetic-oriented people, the wand itself is this gorgeous brushed ombre metal and it looks swag on a nightstand.

recs.content:

I think I still prefer Black Metal 1, but this here is a beautiful & short (10 song & 23 minute) collection of experimental pop tracks that are chock full of atmosphere.

feature.title: #88: Perfectly Imperfect
feature.intro: If you‚Äôre new here after our June guests‚Äî welcome! Perfectly Imperfect is a 2x/week newsletter featuring good ol‚Äô fashioned curated recommendations from real people and once a month the Perfectly Imperfect boys like to drop some hot recs of their own.
feature.introHTML: If you‚Äôre new here after our June guests‚Äî welcome! Perfectly Imperfect is a 2x/week newsletter featuring good ol‚Äô fashioned curated recommendations from real people and once a month the Perfectly Imperfect boys like to drop some hot recs of their own.

recs.title: Trader Joe's dark chocolate half-coated rice cake thins
recs.content: I know. I¬†know.¬†Miss Joe¬†did that. They are exactly what they say they are - rice cake thins dipped in dark chocolate on one side. I've experimented so I can tell you that putting them in the freezer is the way to go. The chocolate hardens a bit but the rice cake stays the same (cardboard-y and delicious). The best way to enjoy them is to take two of them and - wait for it - put peanut butter in the middle. Hello, healthy peanut butter cup! I know it's not¬†actually¬†healthy, but it really does feel like a crunchy treat you'd find at, like, the farmer's market. They're good alone, too, so please don't think peanut butter is required in order to enjoy¬†them. They come in a yellow package so they're hard to miss on¬†the¬†shelves. Pretty sure they're in the snack aisle. What am I saying? Trader Joe's is one big snack aisle.¬†

If you miss his podcast ‚ÄúScrolling with Harry & Austin‚Äù, don‚Äôt worry, he‚Äôs got a brand new podcast dropping in the fall, so stay tuned üëÄ. Harry has great taste and lucky for us, he‚Äôs here to tell us what he‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: Themed Playlists
recs.content: i have gotten into making playlists on a really specific theme--¬†the moon,¬†colors, 'yes', 'no',¬†songs about other musicians,¬†flowers,¬†homonyms... making one that actually flows well instead of a bunch of randoms next to each other is the real challenge. you end up thinking about songs you forgot about that you love. whenever i'm out and i hear something that fits one of my themes, i throw it on the list and evaluate where it lands¬†into the sequence later. my dad has been doing this forever with a group of friends, and now i'm carrying the torch (he is still carrying the same torch).

recs.content: A very talented artist from New Zealand. I met Beach Boy back in 2013 and since then it has been amazing to watch him grow. He‚Äôs still super low key but his product is getting better and better with age and I feel any day now someone that is in some sort of position to elevate his talent more is about to come. It‚Äôs hard to find original good content with fuck all views these days haha here is one of his new videos below and I believe that his new album will be out mid July which I can‚Äôt wait for. BEACH BOY!!! Turn that shit up and share it with ya neighbors. Oh yeah he also produces, masters and edits all his work. Unreal!

recs.title: The vintage-dealing Olivias, @olaroche and @shop_reallifeasliv
recs.content: I love these two Olivias of the vintage world. They truly know how to source and have equally stellar eyes. O La Roche is by Olivia La Roche. She‚Äôs a California babe but now lives in Rome, so all of her sourcing is from Italy. She offers a perpetually going-out wardrobe that will immediately make you feel va-va-voom. It‚Äôs all hot freak-in-the-city vibes. Then there is Olivia Haroutunian of Texas who is Depop famous but has transcended that world because she is a MENSA fashion ID‚Äôer. She finds the most slept-on labels even in something as rabidly looked at like Sex and the City. She‚Äôs managed to track down the real designer of Carrie‚Äôs naked dress, Elisa Jimenez. PS. She is 22 and paying her way through school by selling vintage.¬†¬†

recs.content: I know nothing about art but the one exhibition I ever truly enjoyed was these artists showed the death of Geocities. Shame it‚Äôs over, but with geocities, some of these relics exist, though a lot of links are dead.¬†

feature.title: #86: Flynn McGarry (Gem NYC)
feature.intro: New York City based chef Flynn McGarry became a star after seeing huge success from the various pop-ups he ran as a teen chef, even being labeled a ‚ÄúProdigy‚Äù by The New Yorker in 2012 and profiled by Vogue. These days Flynn has shifted focus to his beautiful Lower East Side restaurant, Gem, where, as the owner and chef, he‚Äôs serving up an ever-changing ala carte dinner menu focused on local seafood and produce plucked at its peak. You can also stop by during the day for a light lunch & cup of coffee as well as wine, cider, beer, antique home goods, sauces, and seasonings. Flynn clearly has great taste and lucky for us, he‚Äôs here to talk about what he‚Äôs been into.

The Lucchese‚Äôs came recommended to me from a youtube search, but it‚Äôs mostly the Roper style I want to recommend (don‚Äôt get me wrong tho the quality is üëå), after countless hours spent trying to find the perfect boot shape for me.

feature.title: #88: Perfectly Imperfect
feature.intro: If you‚Äôre new here after our June guests‚Äî welcome! Perfectly Imperfect is a 2x/week newsletter featuring good ol‚Äô fashioned curated recommendations from real people and once a month the Perfectly Imperfect boys like to drop some hot recs of their own.
feature.introHTML: If you‚Äôre new here after our June guests‚Äî welcome! Perfectly Imperfect is a 2x/week newsletter featuring good ol‚Äô fashioned curated recommendations from real people and once a month the Perfectly Imperfect boys like to drop some hot recs of their own.

recs.title: June Reads - Murder on the Links - Agatha Christie & The Stranger - Albert Camus
recs.content:
This past week, I went to Cape Cod for vacation. The airbnb we stayed at was filled wall to wall with books of all sorts. Over the door, up the staircases, and in all the rooms, there were books stashed about boat racing, insect catching, antique grandfather clocks, a professional mixers menu from the 50s, and so so many more. Naturally, I couldn‚Äôt help myself but take this environment and do with it what I do best - escape into a Christie novel. This time I chose Murder on the Links. An easy to read Poirot mystery with several twists and turns, with a satisfying (if not sort of predictable) ending.¬†

After that, I finally dove into my first Camus, The Stranger. I expected this read to require more effort, as many classics so frequently brought up in psychological and philosophical discussions do, but it was such beautifully smooth read. The story was linear, the characters straightforward, and all very easily ingestible. It‚Äôs amazing to me such a simple book could have so much to say, but it really does and does it so well.¬†

recs.title: Klein Tools Bolt Bag
recs.content: I don't think I'm alone out there, but along with my 20+ totes, I can't stop buying everything that's made out of canvas. The the thicker the better. I recently found out about Klein Tools, and they make small bags and totes for tools all out of No.4 Canvas, one of the most durable and water repellent canvas out there. I'm not necessarily using the bolt bags to store tools, but I've been using them to tidy up and end up being a great shelf decorations.

feature.title: #86: Flynn McGarry (Gem NYC)
feature.intro: New York City based chef Flynn McGarry became a star after seeing huge success from the various pop-ups he ran as a teen chef, even being labeled a ‚ÄúProdigy‚Äù by The New Yorker in 2012 and profiled by Vogue. These days Flynn has shifted focus to his beautiful Lower East Side restaurant, Gem, where, as the owner and chef, he‚Äôs serving up an ever-changing ala carte dinner menu focused on local seafood and produce plucked at its peak. You can also stop by during the day for a light lunch & cup of coffee as well as wine, cider, beer, antique home goods, sauces, and seasonings. Flynn clearly has great taste and lucky for us, he‚Äôs here to talk about what he‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: Douglas Coupland
recs.content: The one author I enjoyed most next to Bret Easton Ellis as a teenager was Douglas Coupland, my first introduction to him was his novel, Generation X, and everything else he‚Äôs written (especially Shampoo Planet, Polaroids from the Dead, Miss Wyoming, and All Families Are Psychotic) are wonderful works I‚Äôve come to enjoy re-reading multiple times over the years. Great author if you‚Äôre looking to binge read all his books in one summer. Most recently I‚Äôve revisited his Marshall McLuhan biography, aptly titled¬†You Know Nothing of My Work!

feature.title: #84: Sofie Fatouretchi Royer
feature.intro: Vienna‚Äôs Sofie Fatouretchi Royer is an artist of many disciplines‚Äî not only does she study painting at the University of Applied Arts in Austria but she‚Äôs the former Creative Director of the Boiler Room, been a Resident DJ at NTS since 2013, and in the midst of the pandemic she dropped her self-produced debut album, Cult Survivor, on Stones Throw Records. Her debut combines the baroque vocal style of 70s songwriters with lo-fi hypnagogic pop to create a lush, melancholy, beautiful, and melodic sound that I really love. If you like what you hear, be sure to check out the music video for ‚ÄúHollywood Walk of Fame‚Äú (made with Eugene Kotlyarenko) and know that she‚Äôs working on her second studio album! Sofie has great taste and lucky for us, she‚Äôs here to talk about what she‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: The Blue Flower I yearn for
recs.content:
The Blue Flower, a short perfect novel by Penelope Fitzgerald, was published in London in 1995 when she was 78 years old. It‚Äôs a dramatization of Friedrich von Hardenberg‚Äôs years as a struggling writer and student, from 1790 to 1797, before he made a name for himself as romantic symbolist poet Novalis, and tells the story of his infatuation with the very ordinary, childish 12-year-old Sophie von K√ºhn. He meets her when he‚Äôs 22 and falls in mystical love at first sight with her. Like many powerful novels, it‚Äôs a book of longing. What von Hardenberg really longs for however isn‚Äôt Sophie, but the ‚Äúblue flower‚Äù he‚Äôs writing about. Some lines from the story he reads aloud:

‚ÄúI have no craving to be rich, but I long to see the blue flower. It lies incessantly at my heart, and I can imagine and think about nothing else. Never did I feel like this before. It is as if until now I had been dreaming, or as if sleep had carried me into another world.‚Äù

The blue flower is what he‚Äôs been searching for his entire life but cannot find, will never find.

What it represents is not explained. It might be understood as a perfect moment of transcendental joy; or the Great Beauty, or the writing that gives meaning to life, the hope, which destroys us, the trembling, skipping longing for the infinite. The flower is different for all of us. The blue has never been seen. We could do with more vaulting romanticism I feel.

‚ÄúThe universe, after all,‚Äù thinks Friedrich, ‚Äúis within us.‚Äù

feature.title: #83: Dean Kissick (Spike Art Magazine)
feature.intro: Dean Kissick is an art writer and the New York Editor for Spike Art Magazine, where his column, The Downward Spiral, comes out on the second Wednesday of each month. For the last five years his column has the covered the topics of our times, such as NFTs, Montez Press Radio, the memeification of reality and politics, ornithology, and how the Summer of Love brought us to this current moment. Whether it‚Äôs his Spike column, social media presence, or various podcasts appearances, he always has something interesting to say about art, culture, and the internet. Dean also has great taste and lucky for us, he's here to talk about what he‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: Tote bags with one strap
recs.content: This is a persistent, immovable fixation of mine: More tote bags should have a single strap. Two straps are illogically floppy. One is always dangling down like a spaghetti strap you constantly have to push back up. Therefore, the ideal tote should have a single, blissful broad strap. So far, the best I've found is from¬†Montreal's Eden Power Corp. It's got a satisfying curve along the bottom and a curious tie-knot design at the apex of the strap. It's like a futuristic mail carrier bag.¬†

So far, the best I've found is from Montreal's Eden Power Corp. It's got a satisfying curve along the bottom and a curious tie-knot design at the apex of the strap. It's like a futuristic mail carrier bag.

feature.title: #82: Jacob Gallagher (Wall Street Journal)
feature.intro: Jacob Gallagher is the Men's Fashion Editor of ‚ÄúOff Duty‚Äù at The Wall Street Journal where he covers fashion, apparel, and what people wear. For the last year, he‚Äôs been working with Phaidon on "The Men's Fashion Book", a guide of the 500 greatest designers, photographers, icons, and creatives, in men‚Äôs fashion. With his fianc√©e Rachel, Jacob also runs Achilles Deal, an Instagram-based shop that sells old artifacts that he likes to describe as "tender, naive and overlooked". If you‚Äôd like to see some of these treasures in person they‚Äôre doing a pop-up at Leisure Center from June 23-27, so stop by, buy some cool stuff, and say hi to Jacob, Rachel, and Bijan! Jacob has great taste and lucky for us, he‚Äôs here to tell us what he‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: "What Artists Wear" by Charlie Porter
recs.content: I haven't actually received my copy of this book yet, but Charlie is one of my favorite writers so I feel safe endorsing this. Charlie used to write at the Guardian and FT (among other places) but stepped back a bit ago to write this book on well,¬†what artists wear. I've missed his writing (seriously, go back and read some of his old stuff, which zooms with zest and clarity) and so I'm really looking forward to receiving this. It is currently only in print in the UK, but I bought it from a store over there that shipped (for free!) to America.¬†

recs.title: Truls Martensson
recs.content: I have no clue how I found the Stockholm-based artist who goes by "@snakeb00t" nor do I know much about him. But his sculptures‚Äîlike a¬†rotund vase¬†with¬†Pinocchio on one side and Mr. Met on the other‚Äîare a mishmashed joy. My favorite kind of contemporary art recreates (whether knowingly or inadvertently) the sensation of plowing through the internet where no two things in succession ever really make sense. It's also just this tangle of absurd juxtapositions. Martensson's work really captures that for me. They're also hilarious in scale‚Äîsee the¬†imaginary Prada money clip¬†that is as big as a toddler.¬†

recs.title: Forthave Spritz
recs.content: You really can't go wrong with an Aperol Spritz on a hot summer day, but sometimes I want something a little less sweet. So while having a bite at Popina NYC I decided to try their Forthave Spritz which, you guessed it, is just a regular ol‚Äô spritz but made with Forthave's Red Aperitivo (which is lovely). It's hard to use this word without sounding like an asshole, but here's goes nothing... this tastes a bit more... complex than the other popular red colored spritz. So fill a wine glass with ice (to the very top), add 2oz of Aperativo, and top off with Prosecco‚Äî enjoy.

recs.title: Ô∏è  Commentary Tracks
recs.content: Since it was Bob Dylan's 80th birthday I figured I‚Äôd check out the commentary version of Don't Look Back (1967), a film I rec'd on PI a long long time ago (which you should absolutely watch). It was fascinating to hear director D. A. Pennebaker and artist Bob Neuwirth tell stories and add some context to iconic scenes! recs.title: Voice Dream App
recs.content: I can‚Äôt be the only person who wants to read a million articles and posts, but can‚Äôt find the time to fit it all in the day. Why can‚Äôt audiobooks exist for non-books! Voice Dream is an app that allows you to import files (PDFs, txt files and way more) and it‚Äôll read them to you like an audiobook! Sure, it‚Äôs that robot voice, but is highly customizable, with options to buy more voices (the paid voice ‚ÄúPeter‚Äù is possibly the most natural E-VOICE I‚Äôve ever heard), and ways to customize the speed it reads and even add customized pronunciations of words to a dictionary. I find myself using this app nearly every day and have moved it to the forefront of my phone‚Äôs Home Screen.

recs.title: Handwritten notes & diagrams
recs.content: Recently I bought a little pack of palm-sized notebooks in an effort to be more ‚Äúanalog‚Äù with my notes and thoughts (pretentious, I know). With a world of increasing options, I‚Äôve found I am all over the place with my notes. I have some in Apple Notes, some in Notion, a few in other random apps I‚Äôve accumulated over the years, and I‚Äôm sure others in places I forget. For the past month I‚Äôve used these handwritten notebooks and it‚Äôs like something finally clicked for me. Just a quick jot away, I‚Äôve got a pad filled and another started, with drawings/diagrams of ideas for projects and little notes I want to be able to look back on. Just make sure if you do this you pair those notebooks with some muji pens or your preferred writing tool for the ultimate experience.

recs.content: If there‚Äôs one thing Blue Bottle has done right, it‚Äôs their New Orleans Cold Brew. Ever since leaving the world of in person work, I‚Äôve been struggling with the loss of my daily blue bottle cold brew, a home brewed alternative is good but nothing hit the spot like the New Orleans. Thankfully, I found that Blue Bottle has the NO brew pack on their site, and a toddy brewing system for the best one-to-one results. Ive just finished my first jug of home brewed NO, and it‚Äôs shockingly similar to the BB one. If you, like me, have been singing the woes of home brewed cold brew options, it‚Äôs time to improve your options!

recs.title: Ô∏è Self Care Coffee
recs.content: After a long year of mindlessly drinking pre-ground french press or instant (shame me) coffee, it felt like a tiring morning task to get me through the day. Recently my friend convinced me to put more love into making my morning cup of coffee. That means hand grinding and measuring my beans to make sure that I can make a consistently tasty cup every single time. It all started with this JavaPresse hand grinder for the beans, and an Aeropress coffee maker brewed using the inverted method for consistency. The difference in smell and taste is remarkable, and I don't think I'll ever settle for less. Sure it takes more time and effort, but it has become a healthy and refreshing self care routine to kick the day.

recs.title: Post up on soft cloths in a park
recs.content: Public parks are great places to post up, see friends and kick back in the company of people in yr community who might not hang out at the same bar u do ‚Ä¶ This was true before the pandemic and it‚Äôs true today. A few years ago someone gave me a lightweight (6 oz?) canvas drop-cloth that has gotten very soft with time & now we toss it in a backpack & bring it with us to parks & on hikes. If you don‚Äôt have a picnic blanket already you can cop a ~$12 canvas drop-cloth from a local hardware or paint-supply store. You could use this to re-paint a room at the crib or make some art -- any ‚Äúprocess splatters‚Äù will just make your picnic look more beautiful.¬†

recs.title: Nitehawk Popcorn
recs.content: Movie theaters in NYC have opened back up, and I live and die for Nitehawk‚Äôs popcorn. I‚Äôm not a crazy truffle person, but I love their ‚ÄúNitehawk Popcorn‚Äù which consists of truffle oil & citric salt. I tried making it at home during lockdown and it wasn‚Äôt the same. Before theaters were open, Nitehawk was delivering their popcorn, and I would actually spend $15 and order this to my apartment because it‚Äôs the best. But go to the actual theater since it‚Äôs open now and order this popcorn! Devour it before the movie even starts! Order another bowl of it! Relish in the stomachache afterwards! It‚Äôs absolutely worth it.

recs.title: Jean Rhys novels
recs.content: I‚Äôd read ‚ÄúWide Sargasso Sea‚Äù many years ago but I wasn‚Äôt familiar with Jean Rhys‚Äôs other novels until my friend Emily Gould urged me to read them, so I‚Äôm passing on this rec to you. ‚ÄúGood Morning, Midnight,‚Äù ‚ÄúAfter Leaving Mr. Mackenzie,‚Äù ‚ÄúQuartet,‚Äù and ‚ÄúVoyage in the Dark‚Äù were all written between the two world wars, and are all slim books about a Rhys-like protagonist: a woman alone who drinks too much and is always in verging-on-desperate straits, between Paris and London. Really amazing if depressing.¬†

recs.title: The Pumpkin Fairies - Love Me (1989)
recs.content:
Despite my tough guy persona, I am an avid shoegaze enjoyer. My favorites are the typical surface level first ‚Äúwave‚Äù of shoegaze i.e. Slowdive, MBV, Lush, Chapterhouse, Swirlie, Drop Nineteens, etc. I could go on‚Ä¶ but there‚Äôs other things to discuss.

For Slowdive fans, such as myself, I was delighted to find their demos prior to their formation as Slowdive, when they went by ‚ÄúThe Pumpkin Fairies‚Äù. The tape consists of six songs, most of which have a strong Velvet Underground influence prevalent within the songs (especially considering one of the tracks is a cover of ‚ÄúStephanie Says‚Äù amongst other more contemporary acts such as The Jesus And Mary Chain, early MBV etc.¬†

This tape holds a special place in my heart as the energy and sound of the band was almost entirely different than their well known records such as Souvlaki, Just For A Day, Pygmalion etc. I have an affinity towards demos in general, however this one in particular, I find the unpolished rendering sends me into a realm where I‚Äôm surrounded by a beautiful wave of noise. I recommend the documentary, seriously, titled ‚ÄúBeautiful Noise‚Äù by Eric Green. The film retrospectively examines three fundamental¬† rock bands‚ÄîCocteau Twins, The Jesus and Mary Chain, and My Bloody Valentine‚Äîand their influence on shoegazing and other alternative rock genres. Another great documentary on Slowdive in particular, is Pitchfork Classic‚Äôs: Slowdive - Souvlaki, which covers the history of the band prior to their biggest record, the negative reception from critics, and their legacy.¬†¬†

feature.title: #75: Rafastinks
feature.intro: How does begin to one answer the question: who is Rafa? Well, to start, he‚Äôs trailblazing the way for a new form of cinema: long form memes. But he‚Äôs also an enigmatic & hilarious living meme himself who is best understood by the distinct style of his IG captions & stories, his iconic full-page ad in the Drunken Canal, his katana that was eventually sold to Azealia Banks, or most recently his Andrew Yang takedown subway posters. Rafa also happens to have great taste and lucky for us, he‚Äôs here to talk about what he‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: X-Large
recs.content: My love for Gorillas is not only displayed by my following of the Momotaro family‚Äôs adventures, as of three weeks ago, I now proudly wear silverbacks on my chest almost everyday. I was put onto X-Large by my good friend Max, a streetwear expert and sourcing god. He knew I love X-Girl by Kim Gordon, and since X-Large is an adjacent brand it was a no brainer. I was aware of the brand's existence but had never really seen pieces being worn out and about and only recently came back in the market for clothing. My epiphany occured when I realized the logo was a Gorilla, and this particular Gorilla is featured on almost every piece in different renderings, I was immediately sold. I think Josh Madden, the creative director of X-Girl and X-Large is a certified genius in my book and look forward to continue repping the GOAT brand of streetwear for years to come.

recs.title: Unsound Rags
recs.content: The day I got to LA after driving across the country, these guys welcomed me with open arms. Unsound Rags is a vintage clothing shop with a showroom in Los Angeles. You may recognize the boys at Unsound (informally known as the "Shadow Crew") walking around the Arts District dressed in all shades of black (besides Rashaun). You might even catch them walking out of concrete walls or stealing mimosas off tables at ZINC. No but for real, this is the only place I‚Äôve shopped at on the west coast. I just recently bought a pair of tan Wranglers from them and it's the best pair denim I own. I haven't worn my Levis since... Thanks guys.¬†¬†

feature.intro: Hailing from East Boston, Sven (aka Tio) just drove across country living out of his Toyota. At his ‚Äúauto body shop‚Äù, aptly titled Tio‚Äôs Auto Body, you can expect to find things such as the Tio Tie, a made to order tie constructed from recycled quilt scraps and deer hide passed down from his brother in law, or the Big Sur bag, a uniquely shaped reversible tote. Keep your eyes peeled because he‚Äôs going to start selling cut and sew graphic t-shirts in June. Tio has great taste and lucky for us, he‚Äôs here to talk about what he‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: Randazzo‚Äôs Clam Bar
recs.content: Sheepshead Bay is known for its terrible fishing boats, Russian espresso, money laundering and of course Randazzo‚Äôs -¬† A 90 Year old Family Seafood institution that offers a uniquely inelegant dining experience. The walls are lined floor to ceiling with fishing relics, family portraits, gifts from regulars and Sheepshead Bay ephemera. If it came from the sea, it‚Äôs on the menu. The wait staff is made up of Sheepshead locals that aren‚Äôt there for small talk. They serve you a tiny plastic cup with your Corona and yell orders across the room to each other. Great for people watching and a great stop on your bike ride to the Rockaways. Stay away from the Scungilli and order the ‚ÄúCalamah‚Äù.

feature.title: #72: Kevin Fallon (Fantasy Explosion)
feature.intro: Kevin Fallon is the man behind Fantasy Explosion, a legendary vintage shop known for its New York based ephemera and apparel. However, he‚Äôs not just stocking hyper-specific NYC jawns, his keen eye for all sorts of interesting oddities leads to Friday drops that tend to sell out before you can make it through all of the pages. So head on over to his Instagram for sneak peeks of what‚Äôll be included on each drop, whether it‚Äôs a hat commemorating the Nor‚Äôeaster of ‚Äò92 or this Carnegie Hall Tee. If you‚Äôd rather see his stuff in person, he‚Äôs running a Spring Pop-Up in Bryant Park, Manhattan from May 31st to June 20th‚Äî so pop in & look around! Kevin has great taste and lucky for us, he‚Äôs here to talk about what he‚Äôs been into.

recs.title: @Voyeur1 (Brian Karlsson)
recs.content: Brian is one of the hardest working street film photographers in New York City. I love his ability to curate photo carousels with linear narrative themes. He captures authentic moments that happened just behind you. His work is a reminder that New York is alive and odd in all the right places when you aren‚Äôt looking. Sometimes when he leaves the Fantasy office in Williamsburg, he walks to Harlem just to take pictures along the way. I‚Äôve seen some of his unreleased projects and you‚Äôll be doing yourself a favor if you follow along too.

recs.title: Miami Vice (2006)
recs.content: With lines such as "I'm a fiend for Mojitos", it's bound to be a classic. The theatrical cut throws you right into its world without wasting any time, and for the next two hours you're in Mann‚Äôs world‚Äî so enjoy the not one, but TWO Audioslave mic drops, speed boats, crime, Mojitos, and more. Not to mention, Collin Farrell in this movie (slicked back hair, handlebar mustache, open shirts, etc) is the style blueprint for summer ‚Äò21. This movie rocks.
